body:
It's most likely a tensorflow 1.14 thing as there hasn't been much change in saved models. Try to uninstall 1.13 and install 1.13.1 as I'm not using anything specific from 1.14, and see if it works.
Anyway, a generic rule, while Ludwig is in v0.x every second digit release could change compatibility. It is part of the reason why we started with v0.1 and not v1.0, the api and other things are not stabilitzed yet, even if in this casethe reason why it does not work is likely tf.

Will try to downgrade TF.
I was pointing that out since it's the first time that this retrocompatibility sort of breaks.

Unfortunately it seems that it's not TF breaking retrocompatibility
On a system that had TF 1.13.1 installed I upgraded ludwig and manually changed the requirements.txt to match 1.13.1 (instead of 1.14.0).
The same issue presented itself with the same exact behavior. I am reproducing it with the latest master.

Might be that you updated the various model templates used within ludwig and it's trying to restore a checkpoint with a different template than the one that was used to generate it?
It seems as it could just be a different naming convention on that optimizer, but I'm not skilled enough to trace it back to the real reason.

I don't think it will be easily fixable, or simply I think you won't be willing to fix that, since it would break compatibility with 0.2+, unless you can find a workaround to be able to support\load both "versions", but I'm open to surprises :)

`stack below`

I just found out that this issue only appears on some models.
Models with image inputs (both resnet 8 and resnet 34), category inputs, category outputs and numerical outputs work fine even after ludwig-0.2.0 and tensorflow-1.14.0 upgrade.

The model that is not being able to be resored is a model that is defined like this:

input_features:
    -
        name: utterance
        type: sequence
        encoder: rnn
        cell_type: lstm
        bidirectional: true
        num_layers: 2
        reduce_output: None
        dropout: true

output_features:
    -
        name: intent
        type: category
        reduce_input: sum
        num_fc_layers: 1
        fc_size: 64
    -
        name: slots
        type: sequence
        decoder: tagger

I suspect the issue might be related to the optimizer used by the input sequence rnn encoder or the optimizer used by the output sequence tagger

Yes that's likely, it looks like they are replacing some TF functions with Keras counterparts, and LSTMs are one of those judging by the warnings.
And yes, I may not be able to fix it, so will tag it as such, but Will leave it open so that if you find a solution you can post it here and others may use it.

Just to be clear, I don't think it's a "they" but "you". I was initially able to reproduce the issue with TF 1.13.1 and Ludwig-0.2.0\master so it shouldn't be a TF-related issue, but something that changed in how ludwig manages models (and my hunch was on how it built the models which have a sequence encoder \ tagger in the definition)

On my side, since it seems to be only impacting "minor" models (ie: the ones I can retrain in just a few hours), it's a "wontfix" also. It would have been much worse if the issue presented itself on image\resnet models, as those require days of training, and luckily I don't have models which contains both of them.
I just wanted to bring this to your attention, because it seems like an unwanted change that passed by unnoticed, and mostly does not do harm... but only mostly :)

@w4nderlust FYI, the same thing happens between ludwig 0.2 and ludwig 0.3, although this seems more obvious due to the huge framework change underneath. Might be worthy of mention in a v0.3 changelog. Errors are more or less in the same ballpark on missing\different parameters for the optimizers

Yes this is expected, there are a bunch of different parameters for encoders and decoders too and other changes to the interface, will make sure to document those both in the Changelog and in the User Guide.

FYI, models trained before 0.3.0-rc1 need to be retrained. There is a breaking change somewhere that causes prediction results to be highly incorrect as compared as pre-0.3.0-rc1.
Once retrained all works fine, so it's just a FYI if some issues get opened for this.
"normal" users won't notice this and should only stick to "0.2.0 not compatible with 0.3.0" as per this original issue
